Can I use a custom XML vocabulary in the response body along with the 207 M=
ulti Status code?=A0
=A0
In other words, if the clients know that they have=
 to interpret the response body differently , when they receive the 207, is=
 it ok?
=A0
Does this go against the spirit of REST?
=A0
=A0
=A0
=A0
=A0
--=
- On Tue, 7/8/08, Aristotle Pagaltzis <pagaltzis@...> wrote:

From: Aris=
totle Pagaltzis <pagaltzis@...>
Subject: [rest-discuss] Re: Query regard=
ing batch updates
To: rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tuesday, July 8, 2=
008, 10:04 PM






* prashanthshenoyu <prashanthshenoyu@ yahoo.com> [2008-=
07-07 17:10]:
> Ideally if everything goes well, then I return a 204 (NO
> =
CONTENT) status to the client.
> 
> But what should I do if some state upda=
tes go through and some
> dont? For instance state updation for job1 is suc=
cessful but
> job2 fails?

You might be able to use 207 Multi-Status as def=
ined in WebDAV
(RFC=A04918 section 13), but even with that it still require=
s
complex logic on both ends of the wire.

You=A2ve hit upon one of the big=
 hairballs when dealing with
request batches. As Roy said recently, any att=
empt at batching
means HTTP-in-HTTP, which requires re-addressing all of HT=
TP=A2s
concerns inside the batch operation (auth, status codes, caching,
et=
c), which means squaring the complexity of the implementation
(of both the =
client and the server).

Are you sure you don=A2t want to simply pipeline a=
 bunch of single-
resource PUT requests?

Regards,
-- 
Aristotle Pagaltzis =
// <http://plasmasturm. org/>
